Subject Matter: The Department of Health must develop and implement a National Biosimilars Policy, whose objective is to significantly increase the usage of biosimilars in Ireland . This policy must include: • Legislation which reforms the 2013 Act and allows for biosimilars to be included on the list of interchangeable medicines; • The Department of Health must immediately remove the existing biosimilar blocker clause contained within the Medicine Pricing Agreement
Intended Results: Increased patient access to biosimilar medicines.
Lobbying Activities:
Low uptake of biosimilars in Ireland – the missed opportunity
Ireland lags significantly behind other European countries in its usage of
biosimilars with only 11 currently reimbursed by the HSE, out of a to

The Department of Health must develop and implement a National Biosimilars
Policy, whose objective is to significantly increase the usage of biosimilars
in Ireland within 5 years.
This policy must include:
• Legislation which reforms the 2013 Act and allows for biosimilars to be
included on the list of interchangeable medicines;
• The Department of Health must immediately remove the existing biosimilar
blocker clause contained within the Medicine Pricing Agreement with
IPHA to ensure genuine competition between biosimilars and biologics;
• The HSE must introduce quotas for the usage of biosimilars in each
hospital; and
• The Department of Health and HSE, supported by representative bodies
such as Medicines for Ireland, must activate an extensive information
campaign on biosimilars.|Meeting|2-5

Lobbyist Name: National Infertility Support and Information Group
Specific Details: NISIG is the only Irish charity supporting and advocacy on behalf of those experiencing fertility issues - NISIG represents the views of its membership advocating for some level of Public Funding for AHR treatments under the proposed new AHR legislation. In addition NISIG is also looking for funding in order to continue supporting their members through regional support meetings, peer to peer support and their 24 hour help line.
Subject Matter: NISIG is the only Irish charity supporting and advocacy on behalf of those experiencing fertility issues - NISIG represents the views of its membership advocating for some level of Public Funding for AHR treatments under the proposed new AHR legislation. In addition NISIG is also looking for funding in order to continue supporting their members through regional support meetings, peer to peer support and their 24 hour help line.
Intended Results: NISIG asked for some clarity around whether IVF  would be included as part of the new public funding model launched by Minister of Health in Dec 2019. If IVF was not not to be part of the public funding model, we asked for clarification regarding what treatments would be included. Also, would public funding be made available to those attending private fertility clinics.
Lobbying Activities:
NISIG made contact with Louise O'Reilly SF TD's office in December 2019 upon the announcement by the Minister of Health Simon Harris of the €2M public funding to be made available for IVF and fertility treatments . We asked Deputy O'Reilly if she provide some clarity around whether IVF would be included as part of this funding model. If IVF was not to be included in the public funding model could we get some clarification regarding what treatments would be included and would public funding be made available to those attending private fertility clinics.
Louise O'Reilly SF TD responded and said she would put in some PQs in relation to these questions and hoped to have some answers in the New Year.|Email|1::NISIG contacted an Assistant Principal Officer in the Dept of Health in mid November requesting a meeting with the relevant department officials to get an update and discuss the following items in relation to the proposed AHR legislation..
1. Update on proposed AHR Bill.
2. Discuss the proposals for Public Funding of AHR treatments.
3. NISIG's potential role in the new proposed Regulatory Authority as the Independent Patient representative.
4. Surrogacy issue; which is a very complex area, how will this be managed in the proposed legislation
5. Removal of anonymity in relation to donor conception, will there be cooling period (2-3 yrs.) to facilitate this transition?
6. How will parents be supported in relation to revealing and discussing a child's origins with them, research shows that support is really vital in order to have a positive result.
A meeting was  therefore organised with the Dept officials for mid January 2020.|Email|6-10

Specific Details: NISIG is the only Irish charity supporting and advocacy on behalf of those experiencing fertility issues. Over the last quarter NISIG has advocated for public funding for IVF, assisting Intended parents trying to reach Ukraine during current COVID crisis in order to be present for the birth of their children via surrogacy; finally assisting Intended parents  encountering issues getting a PPS number issued for their children born via surrogacy in the Ukraine.
DPOs Lobbied: Ciaran Cannon|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Louise O'Reilly|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: NISIG is the only Irish charity supporting and advocacy on behalf of those experiencing fertility issues. Over the last quarter NISIG has advocated for public funding for IVF, assisting Intended parents trying to reach Ukraine during current COVID crisis in order to be present for the birth of their children via surrogacy; finally assisting Intended parents  encountering issues getting a PPS number issued for their children born via surrogacy in the Ukraine.
Intended Results: To confirm that public funding for fertility treatment will include funding for IVF.::To get confirmation that once Intended Parents of children born through surrogacy from the Ukraine, present the correct ETC documentation, it will be accepted(regardless of the date on the EDC) and the child's nationality will be determined as Irish( as detailed on the ETC documentation) and a PPS number will be issued for the child::Liaising with the Department of Foreign Affairs to help secure safe travel to the Ukraine for a number of Intended Parents , in order that they can be present at the birth of their children born through surrogacy, in light of the current travel restrictions to the Ukraine caused by the COVID health crisis
Lobbying Activities:
NISIG made contact with Louise O'Reilly SF TD's office  via email following on from the announcement by the Minister of Health Simon Harris
that €2M public funding would be made available for fertility
treatments in late 2019 . We asked Deputy O'Reilly if she provide some clarity around whether IVF would be included as part of this funding model.  Louise O'Reilly confirmed that IVF funding, would be prioritised  in the SF manifesto and confirmed their commitment to State-delivered AHR services, including IVF.|Email|1::NISIG contacted Minister Cannon via email in relation to securing safe travel for a number of Intended parents trying to reach the Ukraine for the imminent birth of their children born via surrogacy, in light of the current travel restrictions to Ukraine due to the COVID health crises.|Email|2-5::Minister Cannon requested that  Joanne King,Head of Policy & Strategy,Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade follow up with NISIG in relation to securing safe travel for a number of couples trying to reach the Ukraine for the imminent birth of their children born via a surrogate, in light of the current travel restrictions to the Ukraine. GK contacted Joanne King via email on this issue, sending through specific details on the Intended parents involved.|Email|6-10::Gillian Keegan spoke with  Joanne King,Head of Policy & Strategy,Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on two occasions in relation to: 1)  trying to secure safe travel for a number of  Intended parents trying to reach the Ukraine for the imminent birth of their children born via a surrogate, in light of the current travel restrictions due to the COVID health crises. 2} Discussing specific infromation sent by NISIG in relation to the  Intended parents  seeking to travel to Ukraine.|Phone call|2-5::NISIG contacted Andrew Hamilton from Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection, in relation to securing PPSN numbers for children born via surrogacy in the Ukraine,  following contact from
a number of NISIG members who were experiencing some difficulties with this. It was agreed  that once the Intended parent(s) submit the child’s Emergency Travel Certificate (ETC) as supporting documentation for their child’s PPSN application, a PPSN number will be issued. Also once the ETC declares the child’s nationality as Irish, then the child’s nationality shall be recorded by this Department as Irish|Email|2-5
Current or Former DPOs: CIARAN CANNON|Minister of State|Department of Foreign Affairs

Specific Details: Crisis in the Horticultural Sector
DPOs Lobbied: Pippa Hackett|Minister of State|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Regina Doherty|Senator|Seanad::Tim Lombard|Senator|Seanad::Louise O'Reilly|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Fergus O'Dowd|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Crisis in the Horticultural Sector
Intended Results: To emphasise how, while the Horticultural Exceptional Payment Scheme (HEPS) did alleviate some of the pressures on the sector last year, the pressures are still there and the Horticultural Exceptional Payment Scheme (HEPS) needs to be put in place for 2023.::To highlight the huge concern around the outlook for the sector and the huge costs of input materials and energy.::To highlight the need to include all horticulture sectors in any scheme, and changes to the criteria of the schemes are required, especially the basis on which field vegetable growers are eligible.::To recommend that a recovery plan be put in place to sustain and build on grower numbers once more.::To highlight that, with food security currently so much to the fore, interventions are urgently required to combat the high input cost and longstanding issues in the horticultural sector.::To highlight issues with work permits, a bespoke seasonal work permit scheme must be introduced without delay. The fact that the UK and many other European countries have work programmes in place puts Irish growers at a competitive disadvantage.::To emphasise the longstanding issue of peat availability for the domestic horticulture sector. The only measure that will resolve this is to introduce primary legislation to allow for the extraction of domestic peat for the Irish market.::To challenge the penal nature of the Residential Zoned Land Tax (RZLT) by calling for the immediate introduction of an exemption for active farmers. What is in place is a land grab exercise and will force the sale of intergenerational held and farmed land.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tim Cullinan IFA President, Niall McCormack IFA Fruit & Vegetable Committee Chair, Niamh Brennan IFA Policy Executive,  Sean Ryan IFA Potato Chair
